questions.question_text: Which of the following has the MOST influence on the information security investment process?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Organizational risk appetite

Organizational risk appetite is the factor that has the MOST influence on the information security investment process. Risk appetite refers to an organization's willingness to accept and manage risks. It sets the tone for how much an organization is willing to invest in information security to protect its assets, data, and operations. The level of risk appetite directly impacts decisions regarding budget allocation, resource allocation, and the overall approach to information security.
B. Organizational risk appetite

questions.question_text:
An organization's information security manager is performing a post-incident review of a security incident in which the following events occurred:
✑ A bad actor broke into a business-critical FTP server by brute forcing an administrative password
✑ The third-party service provider hosting the server sent an automated alert message to the help desk, but was ignored
✑ The bad actor could not access the administrator console, but was exposed to encrypted data transferred to the server
✑ After three (3) hours, the bad actor deleted the FTP directory, causing incoming FTP attempts by legitimate customers to fail
Which of the following could have been prevented by conducting regular incident response testing?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Ignored alert messages

Regular incident response testing helps an organization evaluate its readiness to respond to security incidents effectively. In this scenario, the fact that the third-party service provider sent an automated alert message to the help desk, but it was ignored, indicates a breakdown in the incident response process

What a strange question. 
No:
A. Stolen data - I don't think they stole any so not A
C. The brute force attack - I still think this would've been attempted, it just may not have been succesful.

Maybe.
B. The server being compromised - This was done via brute force. The brute force attack in turn generated message alerts that went unactioned. As I see it you can make a case for B or D.
D. Ignored alert messages - This seems the most likely as this one was down to human error/bad practice. Conducting more training exercises would hopefully mean people act on the alerts and prevent the breach happening.

Selected Answer: D
D. Ignored alert messages

Selected Answer: C
C. Aligning with the information security strategy

Aligning with the information security strategy ensures that your governance framework is in line with the organization's overall goals and objectives related to security. It helps ensure that security measures are integrated into the broader business strategy and that security efforts are focused on addressing the most critical risks and vulnerabilities. While the other factors mentioned (assessing resource availability, assessing the current state of information security, and aligning with industry best practice frameworks) are also important, they should be done in the context of and in alignment with the organization's security strategy.
C. Aligning with the information security strategy

questions.question_text: A serious vulnerability was detected in a business application that can be exploited by external attackers to compromise the system. What is the information security manager's BEST course of action?

choices.B: Request an immediate shutdown of the application.
choices.C: Report the risk to the business application owner.
choices.D: Ask the business application owner to apply the fix immediately.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Let me give you an example... your a cop giving out a ticket. Scenario 1: Hand a speeder a ticket (report) you have x amount of days to pay this ticket or a warrant will be put out for your arrest. Scenario 2: Nicley ask the speeder to give you 150 dollars for speeding with no ticket given out. Which scenario do you think the $150 dollars would be collected. Obvious answer in that scenario and its the obvious answer for this question.

Selected Answer: C
The best course of action would be to report the risk to the business application owner (option C). It is crucial to communicate the vulnerability to the owner of the application, as they are responsible for managing and maintaining the application. They should be made aware of the situation so that appropriate action can be taken. It is their responsibility to apply the necessary fix (option D) to address the vulnerability. Additionally, it may be advisable to collaborate with the business application owner to develop a temporary remediation plan (option A) if the fix cannot be immediately applied.

Selected Answer: C

questions.question_text: Which of the following is MOST important to consider when defining escalation processes for incident response procedures?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Recovery time objectives (RTOs) are important for setting goals for how quickly you want to recover from an incident, but they come into play after the initial incident has been identified and escalated.
If some one's performance is poor (based on KPI), what will do; just escalate. Hence answer is KPI
C. Recovery time objectives (RTOs)
The correct answer is B

Selected Answer: C
RTO would definitely play a much important role in the escalation process than any other option. 

If an incident is not critical to business and can be down for 48 hours that changes how escalation process would work for that.

Selected Answer: C
Severity of the incident: The first and most important factor to consider is the severity of the incident. with more severe incidents requiring faster and urger escalation. (RTO)

Selected Answer: C
When defining escalation processes for incident response procedures, the most important factor to consider is usually the Recovery Time Objectives (RTOs)
